properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Brooklyn, Tottenham.

  • There is a refrigerant gas leak in a retail premises at 438-442 Somerville Road, Tottenham.
  • Emergency Services are currently responding to this incident.
  • The incident is under control.
  • Emergency Services will remain in the area for at least the next hour.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria. 

Unless the situation changes this will be the last message for this incident.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vichazmat).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - CHEMICAL HAZARD
Incident Location: 438-442 Somerville Road, Tottenham
Issue Date: Tuesday 14 December 2021, 05:25 am
Next Update: Tuesday 14 December 2021, 06:40 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/19237/moreinfo

This message is being issued for Brooklyn, Tottenham.

- There is a refrigerant gas leak in a retail premises at 438-442 Somerville Road, Tottenham.
- Emergency Services are currently responding to this incident.
- The incident is under control.
- Emergency Services will remain in the area for at least the next hour.


There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Walkerville, Walkerville North, Walkerville South.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity at Walkerville North Beach. 
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is assisting Park Rangers with the management of the whale carcass.
Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:
  • If you see sharks report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
  • Take extra caution in the area by swimming at patrolled beaches and not surfing or diving in the area.

Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 17/12/2021 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

For more information on staying safe around sharks:
  • www.vfa.vic.gov.au/shark-smart.
Stay informed:
  • Via www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Call the VicEmergency Hotline to talk to someone about this warning on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • People who are deaf, hard of hearing, or who have a speech/communication impairment can contact VicEmergency Hotline via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.
  • For help with English, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to telephone VicEmergency Hotline. If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.
  • Download the VicEmergency app or follow VicEmergency on Twitter or Facebook.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT ORBOST, JARRAHMOND, MCKILLOPS BRIDGE AND D/S BASIN CK.

Minor flooding easing along the Snowy River at Orbost, Jarrahmond, McKillops Bridge, and D/S Basin Ck.Minor flooding has eased along the Buchan River.

Since 9:00 am Sunday, no significant rainfall has been recorded across the Snowy River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River at McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is currently at 3.08 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) during Monday. The river level is likely to fall below the minor flood level (2.50 m) Tuesday morning.

Buchan River:
Minor flooding has eased along the Buchan River.The Buchan River at Buchan fell below the minor flood level around midnight Sunday into Monday and is currently at 2.37 metres and falling. 

The Buchan River at Buchan will remain below the minor flood level(2.50 m) during Monday.

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River D/S Basin Ck is currently at 3.93 metres and falling, with minor flooding. 
The Snowy River D/S Basin Ck is likely to fall below the minor flood level (3.50 m) overnight Monday into Tuesday.

The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is currently at 4.54 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is likely to fall below the minor flood level (4.10 m) Monday afternoon.

The Snowy River at Orbost fell below the moderate flood level (6.0 m) around midnight Sunday into Monday and is currently at 5.35 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at Orbost is expected to remain above the minor flood level (4.20 m) during Monday. The river level may fall below the minor flood level Tuesday morning.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/12/2021 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Wharparilla, Wharparilla North.

  • There is a hay shed at Odwyer Rd, Wharparilla that is under control.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and monitor conditions.

Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are attending to this fire. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 14/12/2021 06:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for the Mitchell River. 

FLOODING EASED AT BAIRNSDALE

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Monday, no significant rainfall has been recorded across the Mitchell River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Mitchell River downstream of Glenaladale:

Minor flooding has eased along the MItchell River at Bairnsdale.

The Mitchell river at Bairnsdale fell below the minor flood level (4.0) Sunday evening nad is currently at 3.55 metres and falling. The Mitchell River at Bairnsdale will remain below minor flood level during Monday.

The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for The Honeysuckles.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity at The Honeysuckles near Ninety Mile Beach.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is assisting Wildlife Officers and Park Rangers with the management of the whale carcass.
Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:
  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.

Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 15/12/2021 10:40 am or as the situation changes.

For more information on staying safe around sharks:
  • www.vfa.vic.gov.au/shark-smart.
Stay informed:
  • Via www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Call the VicEmergency Hotline to talk to someone about this warning on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • People who are deaf, hard of hearing, or who have a speech/communication impairment can contact VicEmergency Hotline via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.
  • For help with English, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to telephone VicEmergency Hotline. If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.
  • Download the VicEmergency app or follow VicEmergency on Twitter or Facebook.
